dialogues.text: 1995. A modern apartment, all cool and glass. MICHAEL BER preparing breakfast, laying the table for two. He is 51, haired, saturnine. He is doing everything with deliberate quietness, taking the occasional glance towards the bedro to check he's not making too much noise. He is boiling an egg, which he takes out of boiling water and puts on a sparkling clean plate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL puts the yolk-stained egg-cup and plate into the sink, his breakfast eaten, then, as noiseless as he can, turns on the tap to run water. The bedroom door opens, an BRIGITTE comes out, naked. She's attractive, younger. The credits end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't wake me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You let me sleep because you can't bear to have breakfast with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's half-serious. MICHAEL doesn't react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing could be further from the truth. I boiled you an egg. See?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL produces a second boiled egg in a cup, seemingly nowhere, like a magician, and puts it on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd hardly have boiled you an egg if I didn't want to see you. Tea or coffee?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BRIGITTE has re-appeared from the bedroom, now in a dress gown. She's still half-serious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seeing my daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your daughter? You've kept very quiet about her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have I? She's been abroad for a year. Did you say tea?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going. Give my love to your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: And now, thanks very much, I've been working, I need a bath. Get out, I'd like to be by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't mean to upset you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have the power to upset me. You don't matter enough to upset me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes off her clothes to get in. As soon as she does, gets up and goes into the other room. He sits by himself, miserable. He hears her, bathing. Then finally gets up an goes back in. She is still in the bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what to say. I've never been with a woman. We've been together four weeks and I can't live without you. I can't. Even the thought of it kills me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA looks at him thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sat in the second carriage because I thought you might kiss me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kid, you thought we could make love in a tram?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile. But MICHAEL has a more urgent question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it true what you said? That I don't matter to you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the bath, she shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you forgive me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you love me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She looks at him. Then she nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is sitting on the side of the bed. HANNA comes in wrapped in a towel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Well I do. I took something with me this morning.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's another play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL gets it out of his pocket. HANNA has lain down on bed, completely content.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're changing the order we do things. Read to me first, kid. Then we make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL sits at the foot of the bed and starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Intrigue and Love, a play by Friedrich Schiller...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is baking bread. MICHAEL is on a chair beside her w a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Odyssey by Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's an odyssey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a journey. He sets out on a journey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy. Many cities of men he saw and learned their minds, Many pains he suffered, heartsick at the open sea, Fighting to save his life and bring his comrades home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is in the bath. MICHAEL is reading a Shakespeare so to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "And we will some new pleasures prove of golden sands and crystal brooks, with silken lights and silver hooks..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She pulls him into the bath.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is sewing. MICHAEL is reading Huckleberry Finn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I poked into the place aways and encountered a little open patch as big as a bedroom, all hung around with vines and found a man lying there asleep, and by Jinks it was my old Jim...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts acting out Jim, and the two of them collapse laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is at the bottom of the bed. HANNA is lying insid He is reading Lady Chatterley's Lover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Lady Chatterley felt his naked flesh against her as he came into her. For a moment he was still inside her...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is disgusting. Where did you get this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I borrowed it from someone at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should be ashamed. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL reads Tin-Tin to HANNA, who is lying on the bed. are both looking at the pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Blistering Barnacles and a thundering typhoon. It is water.' `But what on earth did you expect it to be?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whisky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whisky! By thunder, whisky. `Whisky? Come now captain, you can't be serious.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, kid, that's enough for today.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They fall back onto the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was wondering, do you think you could get some time off? Maybe we could go for a trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What sort of trip?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to go bicycling. Just for two days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL reaches for a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a guide-book. I've worked out the route. Look, what do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA'S look is so far-away she doesn't seem to hear the question. Silence. Then :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you like planning, don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She throws the book away and they begin to make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First light. Dawn breaking outside the window. MICHAEL is working at his desk, the surface covered in stamps, his collection book open. He picks one with a pyramid on it a looks at it. Underneath, MICHAEL'S VOICE reading Intrigue Love by Schiller.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "I'm not frightened. I'm not frightened of anything. Why should I be? I welcome obstacles, because they'll be like mountains I can fly over to be in your arms. The more I suffer, the more I'll love...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT & EXT. SHOP. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seen from outside, a shop full of stamps. MICHAEL and a S DEALER with white hair and a moustache. MICHAEL is offeri his pyramid stamp, his gestures becoming desperate as the STAMP DEALER shakes his head, clearly not giving him as m as he hopes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then MICHAEL concedes, the DEALER concedes, and a bunch o notes are handed across. MICHAEL runs exhilarated out int the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Danger will only increase my love, it will sharpen it, it will give it spice. I'll be the only angel you need. On this arm, Luise, you will go dancing through life. You will leave life even more beautiful than you entered it. Heaven will take you back and look at you and say `Only one thing can make a soul complete, and that thing is love.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA and MICHAEL are whizzing down a hill together on bicycles. He has a rucksack. It's a rural paradise - hill all sides, a gleaming river below, the sun shining bright She is wearing a blue dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They come to a cafe and sit down outside. They pick up th menus on the table. A WAITRESS arrives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what would you like to have?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you having?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You order. I'll have what you have.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL starts giving the order. Next to them are a group BOY SCOUTS, who are laughing among themselves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's sausages, sausages or sausages. Give it to me, come on, give it here. Let me have a look. You always have the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They all laugh. HANNA watches them nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The meal finished, MICHAEL is alone, paying the bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hope your mother was happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. She enjoyed her meal very much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The WAITRESS goes. HANNA returns from inside. MICHAEL hol out his arm to her, which she takes. They walk away towar their bikes. He is smiling. MICHAEL looks round, then dar to reach across and kiss her on the lips. The WAITRESS watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They get off their bikes at a small church. MICHAEL stops gets out a map and a guide book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, let me show you where we're going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's OK, kid. I don't want to know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sound of a choir from inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL and HANNA enter tentatively to find a choir rehearsing Bach. It is a traditional German scene - whole families singing together at the altar. HANNA is transpor entranced at the sound of the music. MICHAEL watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is in a river, the water up to her calves, her skir tied round her thighs. She is completely absorbed. Then s looks up, aware of being watched. MICHAEL is sitting with notebook.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm writing a poem. About you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I hear it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not ready. I'll read it to you one day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1995. MICHAEL, now 51, is standing by his desk. He opens drawer. He takes out the recognizable notebook. He opens yellowing pages and looks at the poetry. Then flips the pages, to some handwritten lists - the words `Odyssey', `Schnitzler', `Chekhov', `Zweig' with numbers beside them MICHAEL flaps it shut, puts it back and turns to go out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL leaves his apartment block. He gets into his blac Mercedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is listening on the radio to the same Bach music heard in the church. He drives through the thriving moder city. Beyond, the huge cranes and gouged-out building sit of a city under construction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL swings his car into place. He gets out and heads across the road, prosperous, purposeful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An ASSISTANT meets MICHAEL with his robe which he pulls o he walks quickly through an elaborate lobby. GERHARD BADE also in his fifties, also robed, falls in step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right, Michael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd better hurry. You know what she's like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A robed ASSISTANT is waiting outside the door with docume he hands to MICHAEL. They all go in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL joins his CLIENT, just seconds before the FEMALE JUDGE comes in and everyone stands. Silence. The JUDGE lo at MICHAEL disapprovingly, sensing his lateness. Everyone sits. MICHAEL sits, thinking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1958. A sheriff's posse of sixteen-year old GIRLS, come laughing, blushing towards the classroom. One of them is talking excitedly to the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just going to pretend I've been here for years, I'm not going to behave in any special way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just wait. You wait and see.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile together and head for the classroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOYS are already in place, dotted round, as the GIRLS come in. There are cries of `Here they come'. Then the TEACHER comes in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good morning, ladies. Gentlemen, please welcome your new fellow- students, treat them with courtesy, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not far from MICHAEL, a GIRL sits across the aisle, virgi with brown hair, brown summer skin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello. My name's Sophie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Michael.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEACHER comes in. The class quietens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The TEACHER is in full flow. MICHAEL can't take hi eyes off SOPHIE.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone believes that Homer's subject is homecoming. In fact, The Odyssey is a book about a journey. Home is a place you dream of, it's not a place you ever attain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The TEACHER breaks off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Berg, I don't mean to distract you, but we're meant to studying Homer, not studying Sophia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The whole class cracks up. MICHAEL blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is riveted as SOPHIE swims fast and lithe through water. Around him, YOUNG PEOPLE are lounging round on tow It's the social centre. HOLGER and RUDOLF are rubbing the hair with towels as SOPHIE approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael the water's fantastic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's wonderful, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wonderful. It's going to be a great summer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL looks across to where a group of AMERICANS are shouting and playing a very loud game of volleyball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the Americans have allowed us back in our own lake.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are they so loud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You should see their stores. They have everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh sure. Everything mankind could ever dream of.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't like Americans?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just it's more fun without them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He looks SOPHIE straight in the eye. There is a sudden silence, MICHAEL looking straight at SOPHIE. SOPHIE looks down. Then MICHAEL moves slightly to pack up his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why do you leave early?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He always leaves early.

dialogues.text: MICHAEL is cycling back towards town, a smile on his face

dialogues.text: MICHAEL flies up the stairs, then goes in. HANNA is sitti sewing. He kisses her on the cheek as he gets out a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry I'm late. I was held up at school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At once he sits down opposite her. A ritual.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lady with the Little Dog. By Anton Chekhov.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA looks, seeing right through him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "The talk was that a new face had appeared on the promenade, a lady with a little dog."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Schmitz, one moment. We've got good news for you. Your work is good, we're going to promote you. To work with me in the office. It's more money. Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He moves away. HANNA looks distraught.

dialogues.text: MICHAEL is watching SOPHIE swimming, a look of anxiety in eye, when HOLGER touches his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get a move on, we're leaving early today.

dialogues.text: Why? What for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going back to Sophie's. It's your birthday. We're giving you a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HOLGER and RUDOLF disappear to get dressed. SOPHIE appear her swimming costume.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, it's a surprise. We thought you'd like it. We've been planning it for weeks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Really. I promised someone I'd do something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The others are furious with him. They all go off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is cycling towards HANNA'S apartment, his hair we from the lake, looking equally unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is sitting unhappily as MICHAEL reads to her. They both in a bad mood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh kid, kid. Stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothing's wrong. It's nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA just shrugs. She goes and sits at the table to drin tea. MICHAEL is irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never ask, you never bother to ask how I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It just happens to be my birthday. It's my birthday, that's all. In fact, you've never even asked when it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look if you want a fight, kid...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't want a fight. What's wrong with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What business is it of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has snapped at him, razor-like.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's always on your terms. Everything. We do what you want. It's always what you want. My friends were giving me a party!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then why are you here? Go back to your party. Isn't that what you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA puts down her cup, angry. She goes into the bedroom slams the door. He sits, the magic of the day gone. He ge up and opens the bedroom door. HANNA is on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And it's always me that has to apologize.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silence. HANNA lets time go by. Then :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't have to apologize. No-one has to apologize. No-one can make you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA reaches for a book from beside the bed. She throws down on the cover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: War and Peace, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are making love on the bed. It's intense. At one poi she moves on top of him. She holds his head between her hands, as if she would crush the life out of him. Then sh lets go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are both sweating, exhausted. She looks a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now you must go back to your friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL has gone. HANNA washes out milk bottles and empti them into the sink. Then she picks up her luggage and lea the empty apartment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is sitting on the pier watching as HOLGER, RUDOLF SOPHIE swim competitively out to a pontoon, then turn bac full of energy and high spirits. MICHAEL watches for a wh then suddenly he gets up and starts to run away from them all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael. You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But MICHAEL is running away across the lakeside beach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LANDING & HANNA'S APARTMENT. DUSK

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL opens the door. He goes in. The apartment is empt the rented furniture in place, all trace of HANNA gone. H looks round. He looks at the empty bath, the tap above it opens the kitchen cupboards - some coffee, sugar, that's about it. He goes into the bedroom, the bed stripped bare lies down on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL lying on the bed, curled up, in his clothes, like foetus, asleep.

dialogues.text: The family at breakfast. MICHAEL slips quietly in the mai door, trying to go to his room without being heard. EMILY runs to look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's him.

dialogues.text: Sheepishly MICHAEL appears.

dialogues.text: Where were you last night? What happened?

dialogues.text: I stayed at a friend's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown

dialogues.text: PETER looks. He seems to know exactly what's been going o

dialogues.text: Get the boy something to eat. I think we all knew you'd come back to us eventually.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
