dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1995. MICHAEL sitting alone, thinking back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1958. The sun slants, and for a few seconds the water dazzles. He slips his head under.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1995. MICHAEL still sitting thoughtfully by himself in th empty court. Then he looks up. An ASSISTANT has appeared.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr Berg. It is eight o'clock. Your daughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA is already at the table in a chic modern brasserie. is a sympathetic young woman of around 23. MICHAEL approaches. When she sees him, she gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL leans in and kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're uneasy. She looks a moment, then they sit down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Welcome back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. They have eaten. They both have big glasses of red wine. It's more relaxed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So how will you decide?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I'm happy back in Berlin, I suppose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've seen your mother?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wanted to get away. There was nothing more to it. It was Paris, but it could have been anywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Away from your parents?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm aware I was difficult. I wasn't always open with you. I'm not open with anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew you were distant. I'd always assumed it was my fault.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia. How wrong can you be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA colours, on the verge of tears. Then she looks away

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT & EXT. CAR. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They drive through the gleaming streets. It's been rainin Berlin is glistening. Their voices :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I admit it now, I was nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was nervous too. It's silly isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is silly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you for dinner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll see you very soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL lets JULIA out, and is watching her safely to her door from the car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Dad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL suddenly gets out himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julia, wait. I want to ask you a favour.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What favour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to take you on a trip. I want to show you something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tomorrow, maybe. Can I pick you up in the car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA doesn't need to say anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At ten, say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL hugs her, his heart aching with love. JULIA goes to her place. MICHAEL is left standing still in the plaza outside, not moving. Underneath the sound of what follows thirty years previously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1966. A WOMAN LECTURER has a class of about 75 STUDENTS. their hair, their dress, it could only be the 1960s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those of you for the special seminar group on The Legal System in the Third Reich, please stay on in this room. Professor Rohl will be here in a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nearly all the STUDENTS leave, talking among themselves. eight are left, dotted around the huge room. MICHAEL is o of them, now 22, in a corduroy jacket and tie. There is a lull. MICHAEL looks round at the group of oddballs, then finds ROHL, distinguished, greying, is already in front o them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we seem to be quite a small group. A small group and a select one. Clearly, this is going to be a unique seminar. Let me start by thanking those of you who've chosen to take part. Good for you. A reading list, gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL (cont'd) Karl Jaspers, The Question of German Guilt...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A calm STUDENT with long hair smiles at MICHAEL. She look like Francoise Hardy. She murmurs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And ladies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is working alone at his desk, a light on. The doo his extremely modest student digs is open. MARTHE appears the door, silently. He looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So this is where you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Come in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But neither of them move. MARTHE just smiles from the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You take work seriously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're rather a serious boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHE shrugs slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's how I was brought up. What about you? Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure you want to work tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well I do. But I won't work every night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They smile at one another. She goes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The seminar group, long-haired, hippyish, is on the train PROFESSOR ROHL, with MARTHE, DIETER and a few others. MIC catches MARTHA'S eye. They smile. Then he opens the windo cheerful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The STUDENTS are having a cigarette in front of the huge building. Two black vans with barred windows come by, carrying prisoners. The first one veers close to MICHAEL the pavement, then disappears into the inner courtyard. R smiles at MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why all the police?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're worried about demonstrators.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For or against?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A courtroom has been improvised inside the town hall. The are large windows, with milky glass, down the left-hand s As ROHL and the STUDENTS arrive, the court is a melee of PHOTOGRAPHERS, LAWYERS and PUBLIC. The three JUDGES are already in place, next to six selected CITIZENS. MICHAEL the others take places in the gallery

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All photographers are now asked to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The PHOTOGRAPHERS go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The defendants, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From being noisy and chaotic, the court is now silent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing I'm going to do is hear motions from each of the defendants' lawyers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE (cont'd) They're going to be arguing that there's no reason to keep the defendants in jail until the outcome of the forthcoming trial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIETER grins at MICHAEL in anticipation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am going to take these cases one by one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is leaning down to get stuff out of his briefcase MARTHE shakes a pen which isn't working.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want a pen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So MICHAEL doesn't hear as the JUDGE speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna Schmitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a row of six DEFENDANTS. The fifth woman is HANN her hair tied in a knot, her gaze fixedly into the middle distance, not looking towards the SPECTATORS. She is wear a grey dress with short sleeves. They all sit, sideways t the gallery. HANNA rises to her feet. The words seem to c very quietly, across a great distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name is Hanna Schmitz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is only when the JUDGE repeats the name that MICHAEL l up, hearing it for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you speak louder please?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My name is Hanna Schmitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is rigid, blank, just staring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. You were born on October 21st, 1922?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At Hermannstadt. And you're now 43 years old?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You joined the SS in 1943?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was your reason? What was your reason for joining?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You were working at the Siemens factory at the time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd recently been offered a promotion. Why did you prefer to join the SS?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA has a DEFENCE COUNSEL, a young man, beside her, who about to get up. But the JUDGE forestalls him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll re-phrase my question. I'm trying to ascertain if she joined the SS freely. Of her own free will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I heard there were jobs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was working at Siemens when I heard the SS was recruiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you know the kind of work you'd be expected to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were looking for guards. I applied for a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is intent now, so are the STUDENTS beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you worked first at Auschwitz?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Until 1944. Then you were moved to a smaller camp near Cracow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL leans into MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You then helped move the prisoners west in the winter of 1944 in the so-called death marches?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is hanging out of the window of the train, smokin cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL sits down in his seat. ROHL moves to sit opposite him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what did you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It wasn't quite what I expecting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't it? In what way? What were you expecting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL is looking at him. MICHAEL doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exciting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why did you think it exciting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because it's justice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The train hurtles through the German countryside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A student party, in a candle-lit room. MARTHE is singing guitar. It's been going on for hours - the STUDENTS are o the floor with beer and cigarettes. The front door is ope DIETER, beer in hand, looks out to the balcony where he c see MICHAEL bent away from them, all by himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL, his arms on the balcony, is smoking, looking out into the night. His eye lands on a student room in which couple are making love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The small STUDENT GROUP is now rattling around informally the big lecture room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to correct an impression. Dieter said yesterday this was about justice. But is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL (cont'd) If it were about justice you might ask why has it taken so long? The war ended twenty years ago. Remember, there've been no significant trials between Nuremburg in 1946 and the Auschwitz trials a couple of years ago. That's a long gap. What's the reason for the gap?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL waits a moment for a STUDENT to answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd have thought it was obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cowardice. It's cowardice, isn't it? It's bad conscience. It's the big cover-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the war. The German people didn't want to look at what they'd done.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because they had too much to hide. All our parents are liars. All right, mine are. So it's left to us, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we're not implicated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you? Good. So that's all right then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but seriously, Dieter's right. My parents, I can't even talk to them. I don't love them. How could I? How could anyone love them? Because they've told themselves so many lies, they can't remember the truth, let alone admit it. Isn't that why we signed up for this seminar?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. You tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking for myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL is staring at him thoughtfully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did your father do, Dieter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If you want to know, he was in the Waffen SS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are some smiles, but DIETER rides over the reaction

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I mean, that's what I'm saying. So were a million other Germans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's exactly my point. That's why it's better not to pretend this is about justice. Forgive me, nor is it about getting into an emotional state. It has no purpose if it's just the young giving their parents a bad time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a silence. That's clearly why some of them are th

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what is it about? What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Societies think they operate by something called morality. But they don't. They operate by something called law. You're not guilty of anything merely by working at Auschwitz. 8,000 people worked at Auschwitz. Precisely 19 have been convicted, and only 6 for murder. To prove murder you have to prove intent. That's the law. Remember, the question is never `Was it wrong?' but `Was it legal?' And not by our laws, no, by the laws at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIETER frowns, unhappy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But isn't that...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Narrow?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. The law is narrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL looks unapologetic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other hand, I suspect people who kill other people tend to be aware that it's wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL is leaning forward, attentive. HANNA is standing, opposite the JUDGE, who holds up a book called MOTHER &am DAUGHTER : A STORY OF SURVIVAL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miss Schmitz, you're familiar with this book...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parts of it have already been read out in court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JUDGE (cont'd) It's an American publication, which has been translated. It's by a survivor, a prisoner who survived, Ilana Mather...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes I know. I know Ilana Mather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was in the camp, wasn't she, when she was a child? She was with her mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The judge waits. HANNA seems arrogant, defiant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the book, she describes a selection process. At the end of the month's labour, every month, sixty inmates were selected. They were picked out to be sent from the satellite camp back to Auschwitz. That's right, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, it's right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And so far, each of your fellow defendants has specifically denied being part of that process. Now I'm going to ask you. Were you part of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a stir among the other DEFENDANTS and in the cou They start talking to their LAWYERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you helped make the selection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You admit that? Then tell me, how did that selection happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA shrugs slightly, as though it were obvious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There were six guards, so we decided we'd choose ten people each. That's how we did it - every month. We'd all choose ten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you saying your fellow defendants took part in the process?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We all did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though they've denied it? But you admit it. You're saying you took part in the process.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other DEFENDANTS stir with animosity, but the JUDGE i intent, following his own line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you not realise you were sending these women to their deaths?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits. HANNA nods slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes but there were new arrivals, new women were arriving all the time, so of course we had to move some of the old ones on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure you understand...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We couldn't keep everyone. There wasn't room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE frowns, genuinely surprised that she doesn't se to understand his point.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, but what I'm saying : let me rephrase : to make room, you were picking women out and saying `You you and you have to be sent back to be killed.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, what would you have done?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is looking at the JUDGE - a perfectly straight question. MICHAEL smiles slightly, proud of her. Everyone the court waits for the JUDGE to answer. Silence. ROHL is impassive. But HANNA follows her own thoughts. She quietl asks herself a question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So should I never have signed up at Siemens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is alone, smoking. On a bench, side by side, are women. One is very small, dark, in her sixties. The other composed, formidable, elegant, in her thirties. ROSE and ILANA MATHER. They look up, catching MICHAEL's eye. Then CLERK leans in to the younger woman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms. Mather, they're ready for you now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two women go into the court. The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. LOBBY & COURTROOM. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is alone in the now-deserted lobby, unwilling to back. Then he goes to the door. He opens it a little. The sound of the trial. He opens the door fully. MICHAEL can that it is ILANA who is testifying. The court is conspicuously packed. Large black-and-white photographs o the labour camp now dominate the room. MICHAEL comes quie into the back of the room as the trial goes on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL has pushed past a couple of people to sit down ne ROSE who is sitting in the body of the court. He looks ac to the DEFENDANTS. RITA BECKHART, a large older woman, is of a couple who isn't bothering to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In your book you describe the process of selection...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You were made to work and then, when you were no longer any use to them, then they sent you back to Auschwitz to be killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are there people here today who made that selection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need you to identify them. Can you please point them out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA points with her finger at the DEFENDANTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her. And her. And her. And her. And her. And her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The last finger has been to HANNA. MICHAEL watches, but H does not react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each of the guards would choose a certain number of women. Hanna Schmitz chose differently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In what way differently?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She had favourites. Girls, mostly young. We all remarked on it, she gave them food and places to sleep. In the evening, she asked them to join her. We all thought - well, you can imagine what we thought.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA stares back, impassive. MICHAEL watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then we found out - she was making these women read aloud to her. They were reading to her. At first we thought this guard, this guard is more sensitive, she's more human, she's kinder. Often she chose the weak, the sick, she picked them out, she seemed to be protecting them almost. But then she dispatched them. Is that kinder?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA looks back, not apologizing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL sits alone, head in hands, in despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now ROSE is testifying. The court is quiet, focused.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to move on now to the march. As I understand it, you and your daughter were marched for many months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. It was the winter of 1944. Our camp was closed down, we were told we had to move on. But the plan kept changing every day. Women were dying all around us in the snow. Half of us died on the march. My daughter says in the book, less a death march, more a death gallop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL looks along the row to where ILANA is now sitting

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell us about the night in the church.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL watches as ROSE looks across to ILANA. ILANA star back at her. MICHAEL watches the exchange as ROSE nods, a accepting she must go ahead and speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night we actually thought we were lucky because we had a roof over our heads. We'd arrived in a village, as always, the guards took the best quarters, they took the priest's house. But they let us sleep in a church. There was a bombing raid. In the middle of the night. At first we could only hear the fire, it was in the steeple. Then we could see burning beams, and they began to crash to the floor. Everyone rushed, rushed to the doors. But the doors had been locked on the outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The church burned down? Nobody came to open the doors? Is that right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even though you were all burning to death?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSE nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many people were killed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone was killed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did you survive?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I needed to get away from the other women. Because they were panicking, they were screaming. I couldn't stand it. I couldn't stand their screaming. I was more frightened of the other women than I was of the fire. So I too my daughter and led her to the upper floor. I can't defend what I did. It's impossible to defend. I took Ilana in my arms and I led her towards the fire. There was a small gallery at the side of the church on the upper level. It saved our lives. The gallery didn't burn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROSE turns, in tears, to look at ILANA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. I want to thank you for coming to this country today to testify.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The group is back in the big hall. But the atmosphere is grim. It's a while before DIETER speaks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I don't know what we're doing any more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You keep telling us to think like lawyers, but there's something disgusting about this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL is very still, like an analyst who is finally leadin his patient to the heart of things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This didn't happen to the Germans. It happened to the Jews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone is shocked at his violent passion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are we trying to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're trying to understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six women locked    three hundred Jews in a church, and    let them burn. What is there to    understand? Tell me, I'm asking :    what is there to understand?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL can't answer. DIETER gets up, outraged now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I started out believing in this trial, I thought it was great, now I think it's just a diversion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes? Diversion from what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You choose six women, you put them on trial, you say `They were the evil ones, they were the guilty ones'. Brilliant!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIETER (cont'd) Because one of the victims happened to write a book! That's why they're on trial and nobody else. Do you know how many camps there were in Europe?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIETER turns, furious.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People go on about how much did everyone know? `Who knew?' `What did they know?' That isn't the question. The question is `How could you let it happen?' And - better - `Why didn't you kill yourself when you found out?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of the group walks out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thousands! That's how many. There were thousands of camps. Everyone knew.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DIETER'S passion is so great that everyone is shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that woman...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which woman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The woman you're always staring at. I'm sorry but you are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is white. The atmosphere is electric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know which woman you mean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what I'd do? Put the gun in my hand, I'd shoot her myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL walks along an empty wooded road, miles from anywhere. The sun is shining through the trees behind him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wire fence of a concentration camp, deserted. MICHAEL with a back-pack, goes alone through the metal gate. MICH walks among the deserted empty huts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside one of the huts, MICHAEL is by himself staring at line of empty beds. He moves on, overwhelmed, lost. He pa through the showers. Then he comes to a room with vast me cages on either side. In the cages, the countless dusty s of the exterminated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL opens a door and walks into a room with a line of ovens. He walks past them. Then he stands beside them, hi head down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is standing being examined by the JUDGE. Large photographs and maps of the village, with the lay-out of church, are now on display.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you not unlock the doors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He waits. HANNA doesn't reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why did you not unlock the doors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE turns to the row of DEFENDANTS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've asked all of you and I'm getting no answer. Two of the victims are in this court. They deserve an answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA and ROSE are not far away from MICHAEL and the STUDENTS. The JUDGE puts down a bound handwritten documen

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here, this is the SS report. You all have copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a flurry of paperwork among the DEFENDANTS and LAWYERS as they turn to their copies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the report which was written, approved and signed by all of you immediately after the event. In the written report, you all claim you didn't even know about the fire until after it happened. But that isn't true, is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well? It isn't true.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know what you're asking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The first thing I'm asking is, why didn't you unlock the doors?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA takes a look to the other DEFENDANTS. For the first time her poise is crumbling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously. For the obvious reason. We couldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? Why couldn't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were guards. Our job was to guard the prisoners. We couldn't just let them escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. And if they escaped, then you'd be blamed, you'd be charged, you might even be executed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we opened the doors, then there would have been chaos. How could we have restored order?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA (cont'd) It happened so fast. It was snowing. The bombs - There were flames all over the village. Then the screaming began. It got worse and worse. And if they'd all come rushing out, we couldn't just let them escape. We couldn't. We were responsible for them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you did know what was happening? You did know? You made a choice. You let them die rather than risk letting them escape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA can't answer - she has no answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other defendants have made an allegation against you. Have you heard this allegation?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA does not reply.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say you were in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It isn't true. I was just one of the guards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The other DEFENDANTS interrupt to call out `She was in charge'.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you write the report?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. We all discussed what to say. We all wrote it together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She wrote it! She wrote the report. She was in charge.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. And I didn't write the report. Does it matter who did?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: RITA BECKHART has called out from her place. The JUDGE lo at HANNA a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I need to see a sample of your handwriting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My handwriting?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I need to establish who wrote the report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At once HANNA'S COUNSEL rises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, but I really don't see how that's appropriate. Nearly twenty years have gone by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody take her this piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you really going to compare handwriting of twenty years ago, with handwriting of today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give her the paper. Counsel, approach the bench.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A piece of paper and a pen are put down in front of HANNA Her COUNSEL moves to the bench. MICHAEL stares, first at then at the pen and paper, an apprehension rising in him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT & EXT. DAY AND NIGHT. FLASHBACKS

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL thinks back, to HANNA in her bedroom saying `No y read', to her looking puzzled at the menu on the bicycle trip, and to her throwing a book away in the apartment. A this moment, MICHAEL realises she is illiterate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the courtroom, HANNA looks up to the JUDGE to sto the conference.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's no need. I wrote the report.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL, in a panic, pushes along his row, past ROHL and others, who all look up, knowing something is going on. H turns, as if sensing him behind her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is sitting on the steps outside the lecture room. ROHL walks straight past him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've been skipping seminars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL comes into the room and sits down, smoking a cigarette. ROHL waits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a piece of information. Concerning one of the defendants. Something they're not admitting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What information?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL stubs out his cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't need me to tell you. It's perfectly clear you have a moral obligation to disclose it to the court.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It happens this information is favourable to the defendant. It can help her case. It may even affect the outcome, certainly the sentencing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a problem. The defendant herself is determined to keep this information secret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two STUDENTS come in for the seminar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A moment, please. Please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Chastened, they leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are her reasons?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because she's ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ashamed? Ashamed of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you spoken to her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why of course not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't. I can't do that. I can't talk to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What we feel isn't important. It's utterly unimportant. The only question is what we do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If people like you don't learn from what happened to people like me, then what the hell is the point of anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is sitting on the edge of her bed. A GUARD comes to door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have a visitor. Michael Berg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is taken aback for a moment. Then she gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is standing smoking a cigarette in the waiting ar A whole number of visitors, old people, children, familie are waiting. Some kids are playing with a football. Then GUARD arrives and calls out names. MICHAEL's name is call

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is led swiftly down a prison corridor towards her meeting and sat down at a desk to wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is led in the GROUP towards the visiting room. It come on to snow. As he walks towards the room, he loses heart. He changes his mind. The rest of the GROUP go on, he falls behind, watching them go. He begins to turn back

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA sits down at the empty table, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL turns away and heads back the way he came.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA looks round. Nobody is coming. She waits more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Time's up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is still waiting. Then she is led back to her cell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL appears at the door of MARTHE'S room. She is work at her desk. He smiles and closes the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've taken your time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They kiss. She starts to pull his clothes off. He lets he He makes no move to undress her. She takes all his clothe off until he is naked, and she remains clothed. He looks her a moment, then takes her in his arms and they go down the bed. They make love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARTHE is apparently asleep, MICHAEL awake. As quietly as can MICHAEL tries to slip away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are you going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. I need to sleep by myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is standing naked at the sink, preparing herself fo the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is lying in his own bed, staring up at the ceilin not able to sleep. MICHAEL reluctantly pushes back the co and gets naked out of bed. Slowly he begins to dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA washes herself, naked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is dressed now. He stands in front of his mirror, adjusting his tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA stands in front of the mirror, tying her tie. There a small, inadequate mirror in which she checks her dress black suit, a white blouse and black tie. She looks very formal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is led through the prison by a GUARD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A lot of people heading into the courtroom. As the semina group goes in, MICHAEL hangs back. ROHL looks at him as h goes through the doors. MICHAEL is left outside, then goe watch as the vans arrive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA and the PRISONERS are led into the court. HANNA'S s is so formal that members of the public call out. `Nazi! Nazi!' DIETER leans in to MARTHE. HANNA walks on to her place.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone rises as the JUDGES come in to take their places HANNA's face is resigned, without expression. The JUDGES The whole court goes quiet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court finds guilty the defendants Rita Beckhart, Karolina Steinhof, Regina Kreutz, Angela Zieber, Andrea Luhmann jointly aiding and abetting murder in three hundred cases. The court finds the defendant Hanna Schmitz guilty of murder in three hundred cases.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are tears in MICHAEL's eyes as he watches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The court sentences the accused as follows. Rita Beckhart, Karolina Steinhof, Regina Kreutz, Angela Zieber, and Andrea Luhmann, you will each serve a total sentence in prison of four years and three months.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ROHL, MARTHE, DIETER and the students are looking down on sentencing. MICHAEL is crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna Schmitz, in view of your own admissions and your special role, you are in a different category. The court sentences the accused Schmitz to imprisonment for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is impassive, not reacting. Then she turns and look to the gallery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL walks away through the cameras and news crews.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL sits on the train, thinking. The younger MICHAEL becomes the older.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1976. MICHAEL is sitting beside JULIA. MICHAEL is 32, JUL is a bright little 4 year-old in a coat. The countryside speeding by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said : I'll tell you when we get there. You told me you liked surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL walks with JULIA towards their old house. He look round, the memory of coming with HANNA as a sick boy 18 y earlier clear in his mind. The same landmarks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are all three eating at the dinner table, eating a s roast chicken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's grown, hasn't she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. It's so long since I saw her, Michael, how can I tell?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My fault. We shouldn't have come unannounced.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, why's she angry?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL smiles. Even CARLA smiles slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm afraid I've have some bad news. Julia knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL (cont'd) We've already told her. Gertrud and I are getting a divorce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy's going to live in his own house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You didn't come for your father's funeral, but you come for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, it's not easy for me to visit this town.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Were you really so unhappy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not what I'm saying. It's not what I meant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well then?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CARLA looks at him hard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mustn't worry about Gertrud. I'm going to look after her. And anyway, let's face it, she's already a state prosecutor, she earns far more than I do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael, I'm not worried about Gertrud. I'm worried about you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exhausted by her day, JULIA is sleeping in MICHAEL'S arms looks down at her, full of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the other side of a busy Berlin street full of traffic MICHAEL holds JULIA'S hand, a loving father, to guide her across the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERTRUD has come to the door, a shrewd-looking intelligen woman, a little older than MICHAEL, very thin, in slacks a blouse. MICHAEL is standing outside with JULIA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello Mummy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERTRUD leans down and scoops JULIA up, kisses her. MICHA stands on the step, hovering.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you mind if I don't ask you in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't mind at all. I've a lot to do, in fact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't look like it. He stands, not going.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I took her to see where I grew up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You went to the West? My God, what a trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went to say hello to granny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Daddy took you to see Carla, did he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, let's see what's on TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERTRUD gives JULIA her supper and puts her in front of t TV. Then she comes back to MICHAEL.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet she was strange.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She always was. Why on earth did you decide to do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Impulse.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERTRUD says nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I suppose if I'm honest we went because I wanted to re-establish contact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With your mother? And did you succeed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He touches her arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Michael you're meant to be an intelligent man. Don't you know, it's very hard to receive contact if you're not willing to give it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: GERTRUD looks level, not unkind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say goodbye to Julia.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Daddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL turns to say goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL standing in the empty room. It's eerily silent. H goes to his bookcase. He runs his fingers along the spine as HANNA once did. He takes out a paperback of the Odysse He looks at it a moment, then he starts to read to himsel

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is in her cell, folding her blanket. She is 53, a n austerity, a greyness about her. Her cell is modern, but without decoration.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A GUARD comes along the corridor, calling out `Mail'. She leans into Hanna's cell to tell her she has mail. HANNA i obviously surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA reports to the mail room where she is given a big parcel, which she is told to open. Inside, a huge batch o casette tapes and a tape machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is opening the box, taking out the tapes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL gets out a tape machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In her cell HANNA takes out the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL holds the microphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Testing. Testing. 1-2-3.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA puts a cassette into the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Odyssey by Homer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In panic, she turns it off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL presses the recording button and speaks into the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Odyssey by Homer. "Sing to me of the Man, Muse, the man of twists and turns Driven time and again off course, once he had plundered The hallowed heights of Troy... Many cities of men he saw and learned their minds, Many pains he suffered, heartsick at the open sea, Fighting to save his life and bring his comrades home...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. MICHAEL is now walking up and down, in his shorts T-shirt, microphone in hand, still reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ah, how shameless - the way these mortals blame the gods. From us alone, they say, come all their miseries...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Middle of the night. MICHAEL is lying on his back, still reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Who are you? Where are you from? Your city? Your parents? I'm wonderstruck - you drank my drugs, you're not bewitched..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL takes a cassette and puts it into a white box. He writes on the side ODYSSEY 6. Then he reaches up to put i a shelf next to boxes separately marked ODYSSEY 1,2,3,4,5 Then he takes out a small notebook and cross-references t new tape in a handwritten list.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's dark. HANNA is lying on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zeus from the very start, the thunder king Has hated the race of Atreus with a vengeance -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL'S VOICE (cont'd) His trustiest weapon women's twisted wiles...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA smiles with pleasure at his reading.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT & EXT. MONTAGE. DAY & NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A montage of MICHAEL reading and HANNA listening. MICHAEL reading different books. He is animated now, excited. The are extracts from The Old Man and the Sea (Hemingway) ; Anatol (Schnitzler) ; The World of Yesterday (Zweig) and Doctor Zhivago (Pasternak). MICHAEL catching fire with excitement with what he is doing. HANNA collecting the ta from the mail room and organizing on her shelves - her library growing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is lying in bed listening to a new tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lady with the Little   Dog, by Anton Chekhov. "The talk   was that a new face had appeared on   the promenade, a lady with a   little dog..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is walking round with other PRISONERS, in sequence. Suddenly she stops dead, an idea hitting her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The library is right next to the mail room. HANNA walks p the mail room and goes to the library counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to take out a book.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have The Lady with the Little Dog?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna Schmitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The LIBRARIAN goes to get it. HANNA stands, waiting and l at the stacks of books, for the first time seeing possibility.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is back in the cell. She puts down a new parcel and book. She puts the parcel to one side, then opens the boo She then winds back the tape which is already in the recorder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Lady with the Little Dog, a story by Anton Chekhov. The talk was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She turns off the tape. She runs her finger along the tit `The Lady with the Little Dog'. She gets down a small decorated metal tin, and takes a pencil from it. She star making the sounds. `The', `the', `the'... L, L, L, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is working now, circling the word `the' each time i comes in the book. The book is covered in marks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT & INT. MICHAEL'S APARTMENT. EVE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1981. MICHAEL is coming down a busy Kreuzberg street. He 37. He goes into his block. He opens the door : the place much more lived-in. He picks up his mail. Thumbing throug it, he sees a letter in childish handwriting. MICHAEL fro opening it and taking out a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is holding a letter. He looks down at the writing `Thanks for the latest, kid. I really liked it.' He stare then puts it down and steps back stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA stands with a new package. She opens it excitedly. takes out tapes. She looks for writing, a letter. There i none. She turns the packing paper over and over, but ther nothing. She stands, desolate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA effortfully writing various letters - just a single message on each. The pen working agonizingly across the paper. First :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Next:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL continuing to read to her on the machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA still writing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then finally, many attempts at the same sentence, written many times :

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is reading the latest letter from HANNA. He looks it. "Do you receive my letters? Write to me, kid." MICHAE opens a drawer in a file box on the floor. There is a sta of her letters inside. He puts the latest on top of the p and closes the drawer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA stands at her window, in despair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1988. MICHAEL, 44, is at his desk, with the phone in his hand, with a typed letter in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Michael Berg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got my letter?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have it here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As I say, Hanna Schmitz is coming up for release very soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL fingers the letter a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS BRENNER is sitting at her desk in a simple, modern off

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna has been in prison for over twenty years. She has no family. She has no friends. You're her only contact. And I'm told you don't visit her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is sitting quite still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. I don't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she gets out, she's going to need a job. She's going to need somewhere to live. You can't imagine how frightening the modern world will seem to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. I'm still here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no-one else to ask. If you don't take responsibility for her, then Hanna has no future at all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's kind of you. Thank you for letting me know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL puts the phone down. He looks as if he has just b handed a sentence. He gets up and stares at the wall whic now stacked with all the books he has read. Then he goes his balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT & INT. MICHAEL'S APARTMENT. KREUZBERG. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL stands looking out over Berlin from his balcony.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL walks along the road by the prison wall, then goe the guichet to sign in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL is waiting in a small barred waiting area as MS BRENNER walks across the yard to open the gate and let MICHAEL in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Michael Berg?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Louisa Brenner. We were expecting you earlier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT & EXT. STAIRS & PASSAGE. PRISON. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS BRENNER is walking MICHAEL up the steps towards the pr canteen. They pass GUARDS and INMATES.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should warn you: for a long time Hanna held herself together. She was very purposeful. In the last few years she's different. She's let herself go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS BRENNER leads MICHAEL to the door of the canteen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're in the canteen. They're just finishing lunch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL sees an OLD WOMAN who is sitting at a table. Her dress is stretched too tight across her heavy body. Her h is grey. She has a book in her lap, but she's not reading A few PRISONERS are finishing their meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes MICHAEL a moment to realise the OLD WOMAN is HAN Then HANNA becomes aware of being watched. She turns and looks round. At once her face lights up. MICHAEL smiles b but as he approaches her, he fixes onto her inquiring loo and sees the light go out of her eyes, as if she has look at him and been disappointed. He sits down opposite her. smiles, weary.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've grown up, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She takes his hand. There is a long silence, MICHAEL unab to think of anything to say. He withdraws his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a friend who's a tailor, he makes my suits. He'll give you a job. And I've found you somewhere to live. It's a nice place. Quite small but nice. I think you'll like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a moment's silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are various social programmes, cultural stuff I can sign you up for. And there's a public library very close.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA nods slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You read a lot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I prefer being read to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a short silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's over now, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL doesn't answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you get married?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did. Yes I did. We have a daughter. I'm not seeing as much of her as I would like. I'd like to see a great deal more of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After a few moments, he concedes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The marriage didn't last.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you spent a lot of time thinking about the past?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean, with you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No, I didn't mean with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before the trial I never thought about the past. I never had to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now? What do you feel now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA looks a moment, a haunting look, searching him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't matter what I think. It doesn't matter what I feel. The dead are still dead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wasn't sure what you'd learnt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have learnt, kid. I've learnt to read.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL stares, devastated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll pick you up next week, OK?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sounds a good plan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Quietly, or shall we make a big fuss?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Quietly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look at each other. The other PRISONERS have already gone. They stand up. She scans his face again, searching his thoughts. He takes her in his arms, a little awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take care, kid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk side by side, back towards the door. Then by wa saying goodbye, she takes his hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stretches her arm out before she lets go of his hand, then vanishes inside. MICHAEL walks on alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL comes out of the main entrance. He stands a momen looking round at the evening. MICHAEL walks to his car.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is simple, a bedroom to one side, a bathroom to other. It is all furnished with simple functional furnitu The end of a hard day's work. MICHAEL hangs a picture ove the desk - a landscape, reminiscent of where they once we cycling. The job is done. He looks round, grimly content.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HANNA is lying on her bed, fully dressed. She gets up and gets some books down from the shelf. She puts them, one b one, in a pile on the table. Then she takes off her shoes She stands up and climbs onto the pile of books on the ta Her bare feet on the books. Then she reaches up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: EXT & INT. PRISON. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL gets out of the car. He is carrying a bunch of flowers. He walks towards the prison. He leans in to the GUARD who is in a modern office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From the far end of the corridor, MICHAEL is seen sitting a bench. MS BRENNER comes out of her office and murmurs i his ear. MICHAEL is seen nodding, ashen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. CORRIDOR & CELL. PRISON. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two of them come together down the corridor. They sto the open door of the cell. The body has been removed. The books are still on the floor. MICHAEL goes in. A bare tab a chair, a bed, a closet, a toilet in the corner behind t door. There are shelves with books, an alarm clock, a stu bear, two mugs, instant coffee, tea tins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She didn't pack. She never intended to leave.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS BRENNER looks at him in confirmation. MICHAEL looks at two lower shelves on which are ranged the tapes with the cassette machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Above the bed are a series of cuttings, pictures torn fro magazines, showing meadows, hillsides, pasture, cherry tr One in particular : a burst of autumnal colours. MICHAEL kneels on the bed to look at them. There are quotations, articles, recipes, even sayings in HANNA'S childish handwriting : `Spring lets its blue banner flutter throug the air' is one. Then he sees a newspaper photograph : th young MICHAEL BERG receiving a prize from the school principal. The headline `Michael Berg receives school literature prize.'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS BRENNER reaches out for a tea tin from the shelf. Then sits next to MICHAEL on the bed, and takes out a folded s of paper from her suit pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She left me a message, a sort of will. I'll read out the bit that concerns you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL looks at the effortful handwriting on the page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "There is money in the old tea tin. Give it to Michael Berg. He should send it, alongside the 7,000 marks in the bank, to the daughter who wrote the book. It's for her. She should decide what to do with it. And tell Michael I said hello. Tell him to get on with his life."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MS BRENNER looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want to see her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL rides in a taxi into Manhattan. A view of the familiar skyline.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL'S taxi comes up Fifth Avenue. It draws up outside expensive apartment block. MICHAEL gets out and goes in, Manhattan skyline opening up behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A superbly appointed space full of great and expensive ar MICHAEL has taken his coat off. ILANA MATHER appears, elegant, well-dressed - on the surface, the spirit of prosperous New York. She is now in her early fifties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ms Mather?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. You're Michael Berg. I was expecting you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you must tell me: what exactly brings you to the United States?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was already here. I was at a conference in Boston.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're a lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was intrigued by your letter but I can't say I wholly understood it. You attended the trial?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. Almost twenty years ago. I was a law student. I remember you, I remember your mother very clearly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My mother died in Israel - a good many years ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL hesitates for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go on, please.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps you heard. Hanna Schmitz recently died. She killed herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was a friend of yours?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A kind of friend. It's as simple as this. Hanna was illiterate for the greater part of her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that an explanation of her behaviour?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or an excuse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. No. She taught herself to read when she was in prison. I sent her tapes. She'd always liked being read to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA shifts slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you start by being honest with me? At least start that way. What was the nature of your friendship?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was young I had an affair with Hanna.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA looks at him for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure I can help you, Mr. Berg. Or rather, even if I could I'm not willing to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was almost sixteen when I took up with her. The affair only lasted a summer. But.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see. And did Hanna Schmitz acknowledge the effect she'd had on your life?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL stares back, understood for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'd done much worse to other people. I've never told anyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: People ask all the time what I learned in the camps. But the camps weren't therapy. What do you think these places were? Universities? We didn't go there to learn. One becomes very clear about these things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA looks at him, unrelenting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you asking for? Forgiveness for her? Or do you just want to feel better yourself? My advice, go to the theatre, if you want catharsis. Please. Go to literature. Don't go to the camps. Nothing comes out of the camps. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA looks at him, unrelenting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What she wanted...what she wanted was to leave you her money. I have with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To do what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you think fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL reaches for his briefcase. He takes out the laven tea-tin, which he sets down on the table in front of ILAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA lifts the tin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I was a little girl, I had a tea-tin for my treasures. Not quite like this. It had Cyrillic lettering. I took it with me to the camp, but it got stolen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was in it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Sentimental things. A piece of hair from our dog. Some tickets to operas my father had taken me to. It wasn't stolen for its contents. It was the tin itself which was valuable, what you could do with it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits a moment, overcome, her hand on the tin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's nothing I can do with this money. If I give it to anything associated with the extermination of the Jews, then to me it will seem like absolution and that is something I'm neither willing nor in a position to grant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL nods slightly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was thinking maybe an organization to encourage literacy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's a silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know if there's a Jewish organization?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be surprised if there isn't. There's a Jewish organisation for everything. Not that illiteracy is a very Jewish problem.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is the shadow of a smile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you find out? Send them the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shall I do it in Hanna's name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As you think fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA smiles slightly. She puts her hand on top of the ti

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll keep the tin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ILANA is standing at the window watching down to the stre where MICHAEL is walking away. She has the tin in her han When he's vanished, she turns and goes into her bedroom. There on the dressing table, there is a framed photo of I with her mother in Germany before the war. She sets the t down beside the photo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT & EXT. CAR. DAY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 1995. MICHAEL is driving JULIA in the big Mercedes throug the German countryside. He is tense, silent. JULIA takes sideways look at him, but he does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought you liked surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I do. I do like surprises.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They draw up at a church. It is the same one he and HANNA passed on their bicycles years before. MICHAEL and JULIA out and walk towards the graveyard at the side.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MICHAEL & JULIA stand at a deserted grave-side. The w cemetery is seen. MICHAEL stoops down and uncovers a simp stone : HANNA SCHMITZ 1923-1988. JULIA watching, says her name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hanna Schmitz.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA waits a moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who was she?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I wanted to tell you. That's why we're here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JULIA looks, waiting. MICHAEL looks for a moment as if he will not go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So tell me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a moment, then they turn to stroll, MICHAEL talk starting to tell the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was 15, I was coming home from school, I was ill...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk away among the trees.
